rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The penetration of sodium hydroxide solutions into spruce wood and the cooking of spruce wood by concentrated sodium hydroxide solutions
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1927 Johnston and Maass began an investigation on the penetration of liquids into wood. This study was one which had been suggested by Dr. John Campbell as being of potential importance in connection with the manufacture of chemical pulp. The work of Johnston and Maass was undertaken chiefly for the purpose of investigating the mechanics of forced penetration through wood. But these workers made some observations also upon the penetration of acid and alkaline cooking liquors. The results of their researches indicated that further work along this line might be of great interest. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Classification in secondary schools
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A liberal education does not imply a one-track standardized curriculum. The latter is a misinterpretation of democratic and educational ideals. Variety in pupils' capacities and interests suggests the expediency of diversification of curricula in secondary education. Certain subjects must be included in every curriculum, but each pupil's timetable need not show the same relative quantity or time spent in every subject. The provision of a few typical alternative courses would enable pupils to make a selection suitable to their aptitudes and tastes. An initial examination would confirm objectively each pupil's fitness for the course preferred. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ability grouping in education
Education, Secondary
Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experiments on electromagnetic shielding at frequenciesbetween one and thirty kilocycles
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper describes a method used in measuring the ratio or magnetic field intensities within conducting cylindrical and spherical shells to that outside, values being given for various frequencies between 1000 and 30,000 cycles per second of the exciting field and various length and radii. A theoretical derivation of a shielding formula is given for a thin spherical shell and a cylindrical one of infinite length. Satisfactory agreement between theory and observation is found in the case of the sphere and in cylinders of lengths greater than their diameters. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: 1. A vasodilator nervous pathway to the cerebral vessels from the central nervous system. 2. On the occurrence of afferent nerve fibers in the internal carotid plexus
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Already Nothnagel's (1867) experiments made on vasomotor innervation of the pial arteries, lead him to suggest the presence of some Â·other vaso-motor pathways from the central nervous system to the pial arteries than that represented by the cervical sympathetic trunk. He pointed to the cranial nerves, commnnicating with the internal carotid nerve, as the other possible routes for these vaso-motor nerve fibers. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nervous system
Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigations of the secondary tumour formation by Pseudomones tumefaciens sm. and towns on herbaceous hosts
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Studies of secondary gall formation by Pseudomonas tumefaciens on tomato, tobacco, Paris daisy and Bryophyllum were conducted. Isolation from the stem showed that the organism cantravel varying distances up the plant from the point of entrance. Secondary gall production indicated that the bacteria really travelled greater distances in the plant than is indicated by isolations. The migration of the organism is greatly influenced by the transpiration stream. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The physical and chemical properties of the polyethylene glycols and their derivatives
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The present research has been carried out with the object of determining some of the physical and chemical properties of a series of homologous supermolecular products - the polyethylene glycols and their derivatives - with a view to obtaining an insight into the nature of the mechanism connected with polymerization and association, in particular,of carbohydrates and polysaccharides, such as pentosans, hexosans, starch, cellulose, etc. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Certain reactions of gamma ketonic esters
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The gamma ketonic ester, methyl[alpha]-phenyl-[beta]-p chlorbenzoyl propionate, has been prepared and condensed with benzaldehyde to form an unsaturated lactone. This ester has also been condensed with piperonal to form an analogous product. Methyl[alpha]-phenyl-[beta]-p-brombenzoyl propionate and methyl[alpha]-phenyl-[beta]-anisoyl propionate, when condensed with benzaldehyde and piperonal in a similar manner, formed unsaturated lactones of the same type. These unsaturated lactones have a tertiary hydroxyl group, and are therefore lactols. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies of the gastric secretion under normal and some pathological conditions
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The publication in 1833 of the remarkable work of William Beaumont on "Experiments and Observations on the Gastric Juice and Physiology of Digestion" opened up the experimentalfield for the investigation of the stomach. As Sir William Osler pointed out in his address before the St. Louis Med1cal Association in 1902, there had been other instances of artifioial gastric fistula in man which had been the subject of experimental study, but the case of St. Martin with which he deals stood out from all the others on account of the ability and care with which the experiments were conducted. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Stomach -- Secretions
Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of Chinese schools in Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Through experience acquired as a sometime student and later as a teacher in some of the Chinese Schools in Canada the writer has been enabled to perceive the workings of these institutions at close hand and to evaluate their contributions, social and cultural, to the Chinese communities in which they have been founded. To remove any misconception whiohmight exist in the minds of some we should state at the outset that the schools with which we propose to deal are those organized, maintained, and controlled by the Chinese resi dent in canada for the education of their own children in the literature, history, and ethics of the land from which they came. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Schools, Chinese -- Canada
Chinese Studies and Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Analysis of three-phase networks by the method of symmetrical components
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: As modern power systems have increased in size and a network scheme has evolved, calculations of short-circuit and steady-state conditions have become increasingly difficult.At the same time the number of calculations required have increased as has the demand for accuracy. In a polyphase system the calculation of unbalanced conditions has always offeredthe most difficulties. It is possible to solve problems involving unbalanced currents, voltage and impedances by the application of Ohm's and Kirchoff's laws. This method, however, is very inconvenient and sometimes impossible when rotating machinery is involved. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of chemical treatments on the structure of cellulose fibers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the most important characteristics of cellulosic material as regards its technological applications, is its natural fibrous structure. It may be said that the more perfectly it 1s arranged in a fibrous construction, the more valuable it is as a natural raw material. Cellulose belongs to the carbohydrate group on account of its chemical composition, (C6Hl005)x. This empirical formula is very inadequate; the exact structural formula of cellulose has not yet been established. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of the idea of religious toleration in England during the Restoration, 1660-1702
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The problem of religious toleration dates back to the earliest days of history and though great strides have been made since those days, towards freedom of religious expression, it is st111 possible in our own time to call religious liberty 'The Great American Illusion'. (1) In making a study of the development of the idea of religious toleration one may have in mind several methods of approach, and the result of the study will depend largely on the point of view from which the study has been undertaken. One might undertake to defend or to condemn the prevailing tendencies of a period or of particular parties or individuals constituting the period. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: England -- Religion -- 17th century
Great Britain -- History -- Restoration, 1660-1688
Religion and state -- England -- History -- 17th century
Religious tolerance -- England -- History -- 17th century
English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: THE EVOLUTION OF CELL TYPES IN THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM -- MICROGLIA
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This work was undertaken at the suggestion of Frofeseor Wilder G. Penfield and Assistant Professor William V. Cone of the Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery. The original intention was to elucidate the question of primary differentiation in the central nervous system in the development of neurones and neuroglia. The existence of an "indifferent cell' from which either neurones or neuroglia may develop has been accepted in general by pathologists because of the usefulness of this conception in the classification of tumors of the glioma group. Embryologically, however, the existence and morphology of this cell have been questioned. The object of this work was to determine whether or not this cell couldbe accurately defined and to establish exact morphological criteria for its recognition. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Arthur Hugh Clough : an impression of a Victorian
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In modern biography, the scalpel of Sainte-Beuve has been replaced by the kitchen-knife. It is the lives of racketeers and money-kings that will be read and admired, not studies of quaint old ladies, or studious men with moral difficu1ties; water color prints are purchased -- not pencil sketches or etchings. There is a place of pause in such an attitude, andit may well be that at present there is grave danger of this being forgotten. Art has its home with the eternal verities; and the true artist is no conscript to the passing literarywhims of the moment. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English
Clough, Arthur Hugh, 1819-1861

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The kinetics of the oxidation of gaseous propionaldehyde
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The kinetics of the oxidation of gaseous propionaldehyde have been investigated from 120 to 170Â°C by a static method. The reaction is a chain process and is similar to the oxidation of acetaldehyde. The rate is proportional to the square of the aldehyde concentration, and independent of that of oxygen. The apparent heat of activation is 15,400 calories per gram molecule. The following mechanism is suggested for the oxidation of aldehydep {...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Certain histo-physiological aspects of gland secretion
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A study was made of the effects of stimulation, and of section on cells of the eat's submaxillary gland. Sympathetic and adrenalin stimulation caused discharge activity in demilune cells. Parasympathetic stimulation acted similarly on alveolar cells but not on demilunes. Both types of stimulation caused changes in striated ducts but the implicationa are not clear. A true augmented secretion was demonstrated. Histological results showed it to be mainly an increased sympathetic-demilune activity. Section of chorda tympani caused marked changes in striated ducts; alveolar cells were largely inactive; demilunes were in continued activity. Section of cervical sympathetic and extirpation of superior cervical ganglion gave no significant result. Sympathetic stimulation of chorda paralytic glands gave clear demonstrations of the sympathetic demilune mechanism. The results show that for alveolarand demilune cells, the theory of double innervation is disproved. The final word as regards the striated ducts cannot yet be given. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Glands
Secretion
Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Geology and petrography of Viewmount Avenue, Westmount
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis comprises two parts, the first being a general description of the Yonteregian province with a consideration as to the origin of the nepheline syenites, and the second, a description of the rocks of a small area on the southwest side of Mount Royal. A, geological map of the thesis area accompanies this thesis. The topography of the area was deduced from a plane table survey. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Igneous rocks of Duprat Lake and Rouyn Lake areas, Quebec
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A description is given of the geology of the two areas fifteen miles apart; one the Duprat lake area, is situated in a district characterized by massive copper deposits; the other, the Rouyn lake area, in a district of gold mineralization. A comparative study is made of the different types of metamorphosis in the two areas. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetics of homogeneous gas reactions at high pressures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Previous investigations of the kinetics of homogeneous unimolecular gas reactions have never been carried out in a high pressure region. A new apparatus and technique is described waereby it is possible to investigate these reactions over a wide pressure range. This apparatus has been applied to the investigation of the decomposition of ethyl ether. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The inter-relationship of the anterior pituitary andthe thyroid gland
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A study has been made of the physiological properties of the thyreotropic hormone of the anterior pituitary. Evidence of hyperfunction of the thyroid has been shown to occur in the rat and guinea pig following injection of the hormone. The toxins of staphylococcus aureus accentuate the effect of the thyreotropic hormone in the rat. Replacement therapy has been accomplished in the hypophysectomized rat with the thyreotropic hormone. A study has been made of the resistance to the hormone which develops in animals after prolonged injections. A substance which inhibits the action of thyreotropic hormone has been found in the serum of these animals. Animals of several different species have been used. Some of the physiological properties of the antithyreotropic substance have been investigated. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of physical education for women at McGill University
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Physical Education for women in colleges, both in Canada and the United States, seems to have passed through three stages. It was first introduced to combat physical defects as a result of study. The Calendars of McGill (1907-8 etc) make frequent mention of exercises "to counteract bad and harmful positions assumed during study hours." The second stageconsiders this subject as a prevention for these defects, while the third stage though not discarding the first two ideals, recognizes social, mental and moral values also arising through Physical Education. Nary Lyon, the founder of Mount Holyoke College recognized these values as early as 1837 when she said that "daily exercise held in those days a place not unlike athletics ... as it developed team work and the gift of leadership." (1) [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physical Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some studies in the Raman effect
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The phenomenon of incoherent light scattering with a changed frequency was first predicted by Smekal(1) In 1923. It was not until 1928, however, that the effect was observed experimentally by Prof. Sir C.V.Raman(2) in Calcutta. Monochromatic light was allowed to fall on a liquid, the scattered light being analysed by means of a spectograph and lines being found on the photographic plate which were due to frequencies not present in the primary or incident light. These lines are now known as "Raman lines" and the phenomenon itself as the "Raman Effect." [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Raman effect
Physics
Light

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The investigation of gaseous oxidation processes by the method of dilute flames
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An attempt was made to investigate the oxidation of zinc ethyl by the method of ~dilute flames". However, no flame could be obtained even at quite high temperatures and pressures. Furthermore, there was no evidence of any reaction whatever at the low pressures used. The oxidation of zinc ethyl is always accompanied by the deposition of a white precipitate,and this could not be observed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Insoluble methanol-lignin : a contribution to the study of lignin
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the past few years, considerable work has been carried out in these laboratories on the isolation of lignin. Particular attention has been paid to the use of hydroxylatedsolvents in the presence of catalysts. The pioneer work was carried out by H. J. Rowley (1), who introduced the use of glycol and was able to extract about one half of the ligninby this means, though the recovery was appreciably less. It was shown (4) that the presence of glycol gives rise to false methoxyl values, and this solvent was therefore replaced by methyl alcohol (2, 3, 4). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cyto-genetic studies of steriloid and sub-fatuoid oats
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: False wild oats or fatuoids, so-called because of the resemblance they bear to the wild oat Avena fatua, have been found in most varieties of A. sativa and A. byzantina and areanalogous to the speltoids occurring in wheats. The most remarkable feature of the various futuoids is that regardless of the strain in which they originate the one complex ofcharacters involved, namely, callus pubescence, articulation and awning, is common to all fatuoids. In all other morphological characteristics fatuoids resemble the strains in which they originate. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Genetics
